Chapter 9: Stigma

Stigma is central to the experience that HIV+ communities have with HIV/AIDS. From the start of the pandemic through to now, the stigma associated with the disease for a raft of reasons has significantly affected our ability to control the transmission of HIV through good prevention activities. A history connected to prostitution and drug use, and an association with social taboos such as homosexuality, has ensured that HIV needs to be treated clinically, socially and psychologically. This is a complex mix to get right, and while care has improved it’s an ongoing battle to fix the associations the public holds of HIV and people who have HIV.
